questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing swelling and pain of his right knee for the past month. He has not had any trauma to the knee or previous problems with his joints. He has hypertension. His only medication is hydrochlorothiazide. He works as a carpet installer. He drinks two to three beers daily. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 97 kg (214 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination of the right knee shows swelling and erythema; there is fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. The range of flexion is limited because of the pain. The skin over the site of his pain is not warm. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella; there is no joint line tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute gout attacks typically manifest as intense pain and inflammation in the big toe (podagra), knee, fingers, or wrists. Although this patient has many risk factors for gout (including male sex, obesity, hypertension, and alcohol intake), acute gout attacks usually become maximally painful over a few hours, not one month. In addition, gout usually causes warmth over the affected joint, which is not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis characteristically manifests with monoarticular pain and swelling, as seen in this patient. However, patients with septic arthritis also have systemic signs of infection such as fever and leukocytosis. Additionally, septic arthritis has an acute course and rarely evolves over the course of one month. Finally, because joint infection in septic arthritis occurs via hematogenous spread or direct contamination, most patients will have either a concomitant infection (e.g. endocarditis, abscess) or significant trauma to the affected joint

C) CORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the synovial bursa located between the skin and patella. It is often caused by overuse injuries (such as excessive kneeling, as seen in this case) or repeated trauma to the knee. Professions which require frequent kneeling (e.g., carpet installers, masons, plumbers, mechanics) are especially prone to developing prepatellar bursitis. In acute bursitis, bursal fluid aspiration is indicated to rule out infection or gout. Treatment is conservative and involves rest, ice or heat, elevation, NSAIDs, and, in case of infection, antibiotics. Surgery may be indicated (e.g., drainage of pus, bursectomy) for recurrent bursitis if conservative management fails.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disabling joint disease characterized by a noninflammatory degeneration of the joint complex that occurs with old age or from overuse. Although patients with osteoarthritis can also present with unilateral knee pain, they generally do not have fluctuant edema over the prepatellar bursa. Additionally, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in a 37-year-old patient unless there was a history of significant trauma to the knee.

E) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease commonly manifests as anterior knee pain exacerbated by physical activity in adolescent boys. Patients characteristically have point tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. This diagnosis is unlikely in a 37-year-old with tenderness over the patella and not the tibial tuberosity.
Image Description:

Left knee of a 31-year-old patient

The tibial tuberosity has remained prominent in adulthood (red overlay) secondary to Osgood-Schlatter disease in adolescence.
questions.hint: This condition commonly occurs in individuals with occupations that require excessive kneeling.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician for 1 month of worsening right knee pain. He has not had any trauma other than stubbing his toe 3 days ago at the garage where he works as a mechanic. Examination of the right knee shows swelling and erythema with fluctuance over the inferior patella. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella but no joint line tenderness or warmth. The range of flexion is limited because of the pain. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Deposition of crystals in the joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the patellar tendon causes patellar tendonitis. This condition is most often the result of overuse (especially with running and jumping activities) and manifests with progressive anterior knee pain and swelling, similar to that described by this patient. However, the presence of a fluctuant collection overlying the patella is inconsistent and argues strongly against this diagnosis.

Inflammation of the insertion of the patellar tendon onto the tibial tuberosity and its subsequent disruption (apophysitis) is the cause of the pediatric condition Osgood-Schlatter disease.
Image Description:

Left knee of a 31-year-old patient

The tibial tuberosity has remained prominent in adulthood (red overlay) secondary to Osgood-Schlatter disease in adolescence.

B) INCORRECT:

Noninflammatory degeneration of the joint is seen in osteoarthritis. This is most often attributed to old age or chronic overuse of the joint. Although patients with osteoarthritis can also present with unilateral knee pain, they generally do not have appreciable fluctuance over the prepatellar bursa. Additionally, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in a 42-year-old patient unless there was a history of significant trauma to the knee.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection of the joint is the underlying cause of septic arthritis, which usually manifests as monoarticular pain and swelling, as seen in this patient. However, patients with septic arthritis also have systemic signs of infection such as fever. Additionally, septic arthritis has an acute course and rarely evolves over the course of one month. Finally, because joint infection in septic arthritis occurs via hematogenous spread or direct contamination, most patients will have either a concomitant infection (e.g. endocarditis or abscess) or significant trauma to the affected joint, neither of which are present.

D) INCORRECT:

Deposition of uric acid crystals in the joint can cause acute gout attacks, which manifest as intense pain and inflammation in the big toe (podagra), knee, fingers, or wrists. Acute gout attacks usually become maximally painful over the span of a few hours, not one month. In addition, gout usually causes warmth over the affected joint, which is not seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the synovial bursa located between the skin and patella. It is often caused by overuse injuries or repeated trauma to the knee. Professions which require frequent kneeling (e.g., carpet installers, masons, plumbers, mechanics) are especially prone to developing prepatellar bursitis. The condition most often manifests with localized swelling, tenderness on palpation and with range of motion, and a palpable fluid collection (the inflamed bursa), all of which are observed in this patient; fever, warmth, or spreading erythema are characteristically absent.

Surgery may be indicated (e.g., drainage of pus, bursectomy) for recurrent bursitis if conservative management fails.
questions.hint: This condition commonly occurs in individuals with occupations that require excessive kneeling.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of right-sided knee pain. He works as a bricklayer and reports that the pain worsens when he kneels. He has no history of trauma. Examination of the right knee shows erythema, fluctuant swelling, and tenderness on palpation of the kneecap. Passive flexion of the right knee elicits pain. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle (i.e., Osgood-Schlatter disease) is an overuse injury caused by repeated strain of the patellar ligament on this structure (e.g., during sprinting and jumping sports). This condition manifests with anterior knee pain that is worse with activity and extension against resistance. However, physical examination would show enlargement and tenderness to palpation over the tibial tubercle rather than the patella. Additionally, Osgood-Schlatter disease is not associated with repetitive kneeling and is seen most commonly in teenage males.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the anserine bursa, which is located below the pes anserinus tendon, can lead to anteromedial tibial pain, especially when rising from a seated position or climbing stairs. Physical examination would show swelling and tenderness to palpation of the medial side of the knee and proximal tibia rather than over the patella. Moreover, this patient does not have any known risk factors for pes anserine pain syndrome, e.g., knee osteoarthritis, obesity, or valgus knee deformity.

C) INCORRECT:

Overuse of the knee (e.g., excessive kneeling or squatting) can lead to chronic degenerative changes of the medial meniscus in middle-aged to older adults. Patients often present with knee pain that is worse with weight‑bearing or physical activity. However, a degenerative meniscus injury typically manifests with restricted knee extension and knee instability, which patients describe as a feeling of a knee locking or “giving out” while walking or climbing stairs, none of which is seen here. Additionally, physical examination would show medial joint line tenderness with positive testing (e.g., McMurray test, Apley grind test) rather than patellar erythema, tenderness, and swelling.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the suprapatellar bursa, which is located above the kneecap and facilitates movement of the quadriceps tendons over the femur during knee flexion and extension, can be caused by repeated flexion of the knee joint (e.g., repeated kneeling during bricklaying). However, physical examination would show erythema, swelling, and tenderness to palpation above the kneecap rather than over the anterior patella.

E) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the synovial membrane can indicate an inflammatory joint disease such as rheumatoid arthritis (RA). RA usually manifests with symmetrical polyarthritis (most commonly in MCP and PIP joints) with prolonged morning stiffness. Unilateral pain and swelling of the knee, as seen in this patient, is a less likely first manifestation of RA. Moreover, local erythema is usually not seen in RA. Finally, the fact that this patient must kneel as part of his job puts him at risk for damage of a different structure.

F) CORRECT:

Inflammation of the prepatellar bursa, which is located between the skin and kneecap, can be caused by repeated flexion of the knee joint or recurrent trauma. Individuals with jobs that require frequent kneeling (e.g., bricklayers, plumbers, mechanics) are especially prone to developing prepatellar bursitis. The condition commonly manifests with localized erythema, fluctuant swelling (the inflamed bursa), and tenderness to palpation and movement of the kneecap, all of which are observed in this patient. Surgery may be indicated (e.g., drainage of pus, bursectomy) for recurrent bursitis if conservative management fails.
questions.hint: This patient's occupational history puts him at risk for an overuse injury known as housemaid's knee.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of 4-day history of fatigue and right knee pain. He spent 6 hours the day before the symptoms began laying floor tiles in his new home. He has hypertension and monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance. His medications are lisinopril and a daily multivitamin. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He works as a carpenter. He is 180 cm (5 ft 9in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 141/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender, warm, erythematous right knee. There is a palpable prepatellar swelling. The end range of active right knee extension is limited by pain; passive range of motion is normal. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injection can be used to treat chronic osteoarthritis, which can manifest with knee pain and swelling in an older individual. However, the onset of pain in osteoarthritis is insidious, rather than acute. Moreover, erythema, fever, tachycardia, and fatigue suggest an infection, which is a contraindication for intraarticular glucocorticoid injections. This patient's prepatellar swelling and normal range of motion indicate that the source of his symptoms is located outside of the joint.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral dicloxacillin therapy is indicated for septic bursitis that is caused by an organism susceptible to dicloxacillin, such as Staphylococcus aureus, which is the most common causal organism. Patients with septic bursitis are initially treated with empiric antibiotic therapy until the causative pathogen is identified. In addition, a different step in management is indicated before treatment is begun.

C) CORRECT:

Diagnostic bursal fluid aspiration is indicated in all patients who have bursitis in a superficial bursa. The aspirated fluid should be analyzed for infection via Gram stain, bacterial culture, and a white blood cell count with differential, as well as for crystal arthropathies via examination under a polarizing microscope. An immunocompromised state (e.g., monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance) is a risk factor for developing septic bursitis, which can manifest acutely with local findings as well as fatigue, myalgia, and/or fever. Empiric antibiotics against staphylococci and streptococci should be initiated in this patient after fluid aspiration and adjusted according to bursal fluid culture results. Imaging is usually unnecessary unless bone involvement is suspected. Complications of bursal fluid aspiration include spread of infection to the adjacent bursa or joint.

D) INCORRECT:

Rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE) is indicated for the initial treatment of noninfectious bursitis. This patient, however, has additional signs of infection, such as fever, fatigue, and tachycardia. Therefore, he requires another form of management before conservative therapy is initiated.

E) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy of the knee may be indicated in patients with suspected intraarticular pathology (e.g., meniscal injuries). However, this patient has a prepatellar swelling, which indicates an extraarticular pathology. In addition, this patient has a normal range of motion in his knee joint, making an intraarticular pathology unlikely.
questions.hint: Acute anterior knee pain, erythema, warmth, and localized swelling anterior to the patella after prolonged activity on the knees, which can result in superficial skin abrasions, strongly suggest prepatellar bursitis.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old woman reports a 2-day history of pain over her right elbow. She does not recall any specific trauma to the area. She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with prednisone 5 mg daily.
On examination, her temperature is 37.1°C, her heart rate is 94 beats per minutes, and her blood pressure is 115/81 mm Hg. Her elbow is erythematous and warm to the touch. There is an effusion overlying the olecranon bursa. The patient can fully extend her elbow without increased discomfort, but pain is elicited with passive flexion of the elbow. None of her other joints is tender or swollen. There are rheumatoid nodules over the forearms, and there is ulnar deviation of the fingers.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the elbow
Increase the dose of prednisone to 60 mg daily

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging studies, such as CT, are not typically helpful in the setting of a nontraumatic, acute olecranon bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Initiating treatment with colchicine would only be appropriate for gout, which is unlikely in this patient and would require proof by aspiration in any case.

C) CORRECT:

The olecranon bursa can become inflamed from an infection, crystalline disease, or other systemic disease that causes an inflammatory arthropathy. Septic olecranon bursitis typically causes acute pain, erythema, and warmth of the affected elbow. Fever and leukocytosis are common but not universal. Progression to joint infection or septicemia can occur if an infection is not identified and treated properly.

When the cause of acute olecranon bursitis is not apparent, fluid aspiration from an acutely inflamed bursa is warranted because it can distinguish an infection from a noninfectious inflammatory etiology. The bursa fluid should be sent for cell count, differential, Gram stain, culture, and crystal analysis. The cell count in septic bursitis is usually much lower than in septic arthritis, so an initial finding of only mild inflammation does not rule out infection. Serial drainage of a septic bursa may be necessary to clear the infection.

Key learning point: The primary evaluation of acute olecranon bursitis consists of aspirating the bursa and sending the fluid for cell count, differential, Gram stain, bacterial culture, and crystal analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Increasing the dose of prednisone is not appropriate because although a rheumatoid arthritis flare can cause bursitis, it would be unlikely to cause an isolated olecranon bursitis without other joint involvement.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism in most cases of culture-proven septic bursitis. Treatment with antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole alone is often inadequate without proper drainage.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old female nursing home resident with a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, and mild dementia presents with pain in the left buttock that she says has occurred intermittently for several years. The pain is worsened by prolonged sitting and relieved by standing and taking a few steps. She spends most of her day sitting in a wooden chair playing cards. The pain radiates down her thigh but not below the knee.
On examination, she has no pain upon internal and external rotation of either hip. A straight-leg-raise test to 65 degrees is negative. Range of motion in the lumbar spine is preserved, but bending forward induces the pain in the left buttock, the lower portion of which has marked tenderness to palpation.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prolonged sitting can lead to irritation of the bursa overlying the ischial prominence, resulting in the clinical syndrome of ischiogluteal bursitis. The pain of ischiogluteal bursitis is exacerbated by direct pressure on the bursa, as occurs with sitting or with palpation over the ischial prominence, and may radiate down the posterior hip. Effective management includes identifying and avoiding typical triggers, such as prolonged sitting on a firm surface.

Key learning point: Pain and point tenderness over the ischial tuberosity, often precipitated by chronic pressure on the bursa, is attributable to ischiogluteal bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Iliopectineal bursitis causes anterior hip pain and tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

A compression fracture is characterized by tenderness over the affected vertebral body in the midline spine.

D) INCORRECT:

Spinal stenosis causes neurogenic claudication, particularly in the thighs; is not associated with point tenderness; and is more likely to be worsened by standing and walking and to be alleviated by sitting.

E) INCORRECT:

Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (formerly referred to as trochanteric bursitis) is exacerbated by pressure over the trochanteric bursa over the lateral hip.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man reports a mild throbbing pain in the front of his right knee. The pain started approximately 3 weeks ago and is present only on flexing of the right knee. The patient works as a plumber and occasionally jogs. He reports no recent trauma, and his walking is not affected. He has no medical history and takes no medications.
The patient's vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals tenderness and mild edema in front of the patella. No effusion is present. The range of motion is normal, but pain is elicited with full flexion of the knee. Anterior and posterior drawer tests and a McMurray test are negative.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A positive McMurray test would suggest a meniscal tear, which is usually accompanied by trauma, particularly in a young person.

B) INCORRECT:

Tenderness on palpation at the medial proximal tibia would be consistent with anserine bursitis.

C) INCORRECT:

A drawer test is likely to elicit pain or instability in a patient with an anterior cruciate ligament injury.

D) INCORRECT:

A drawer test is likely to elicit pain or instability in a patient with a posterior cruciate ligament injury.

E) CORRECT:

Prepatellar and superficial infrapatellar bursitis are caused by irritation, inflammation, or infection of the prepatellar and superficial infrapatellar bursae, which are located anterior to the patella and the patellar tendon, respectively. Repetitively being on one’s knees can cause prepatellar bursitis, which frequently occurs in tile-layers, plumbers, housekeepers, and those who kneel for religious reasons. Additional causes of prepatellar bursitis include trauma, infection, gout, and rheumatoid arthritis.

Signs of prepatellar or infrapatellar bursitis on physical examination include focal tenderness, warmth, and bursal swelling. Joint effusion, if present, is often small and secondary to the bursal inflammation (a process termed “sympathetic effusion”). If a large knee effusion is present, it suggests a concurrent articular process. Pain is often exacerbated by passive flexion of the knee, but extension is not impaired and is often a preferred position because intrabursal pressure is at its lowest.

Key learning point: Localized tenderness and edema anterior to the patella is indicative of prepatellar bursitis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with swelling and pain in her right elbow. She has no medical history, takes no medications, and reports no recent trauma or injury. She works as a waitress.
On physical examination, she is afebrile and has normal vital signs. The right elbow is erythematous, and the posterior elbow is swollen and exhibits a palpable fluid collection that is warm and tender on palpation. There is no loss of skin integrity overlying the bursa. She is able to extend, flex, supinate, and pronate her right forearm without difficulty. Mild pain is elicited by complete flexion of the elbow. Examination is otherwise normal.
Aspiration of the fluid collection yields 5 mL of bloody fluid.
In addition to applying a compression dressing and recommending joint protection, which one of the following management options is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Oral prednisone 20 mg daily for 7 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrabursal glucocorticoid injections may be useful for inflammatory causes of olecranon bursitis, such as gout. In the setting of a post-traumatic olecranon bursitis, intrabursal glucocorticoids raise the risk of introducing infection or creating a nonhealing draining sinus tract from the bursa to the skin.

B) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular fibrinogen injection is not approved as a hemostatic agent and has no demonstrated efficacy for this purpose.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of empiric antibiotics while awaiting culture results would be appropriate for olecranon bursitis in which the aspirate is inflammatory or purulent. Septic olecranon bursitis often is accompanied by a skin injury as a likely portal of entry for bacteria, and septic bursitis often requires intravenous antibiotics.

D) CORRECT:

Hemorrhagic olecranon bursitis is caused by direct pressure or trauma on the olecranon fossa at the posterior elbow. The trauma that results in hemorrhagic olecranon bursitis may be repeated and minor, even in healthy people, or caused by an isolated traumatic event. Occupational hazards such as desk work, waiting tables, and carpentry are associated with olecranon bursitis, and the antecedent trauma may have been mild enough to not be recalled by the patient. Traumatic olecranon bursitis is also known as barfly elbow or student’s elbow.

Aspiration of the bursal fluid in patients with hemorrhagic olecranon bursitis may be diagnostic and therapeutic. Aspiration of an erythematous, swollen, tender hemorrhagic bursa permits assessment for possible septic bursitis (a separate, more serious condition). Decompression of the bursa often relieves pain. Imaging is usually unnecessary if elbow movements are intact. Joint protection, including use of an orthosis, should be implemented to shield the bursa from external pressure. Beyond these interventions, observation is sufficient.

The use of empiric antibiotics while awaiting culture results would be appropriate for olecranon bursitis in which the aspirate is inflammatory or purulent. Septic olecranon bursitis often is accompanied by a skin injury as a likely portal of entry for bacteria, and septic bursitis often requires intravenous antibiotics.

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or intrabursal glucocorticoid injections may be useful for inflammatory causes of olecranon bursitis, such as gout. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs would be appropriate for pain relief in traumatic bursitis with nonhemorrhagic fluid, but they could prolong bleeding.

Key learning point: After aspiration of the affected bursa, application of a compression dressing, and recommendations for joint protection, the most appropriate management approach for hemorrhagic olecranon bursitis is observation.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no role for oral glucocorticoids in a post-traumatic olecranon bursitis as they are ineffective.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old generally healthy man presents to the emergency department reporting progressive erythema, pain, and swelling around his left elbow for the past 3 days. Four days earlier, he was working in his attic, crawling around on his elbows and knees. Afterward, he noticed several scratches on his elbows and knees. He has no history of joint swelling, and no other joints are affected. He denies subjective fevers or chills and otherwise feels well.
He has a temperature of 38.1°C, a heart rate of 74 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 124/76 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals erythema and marked swelling around the posterior elbow. The elbow has full extension, but flexion is limited by pain. A boggy fluid collection is evident over the olecranon.
Complete aspiration of the olecranon bursa yields 8 mL of mildly cloudy yellow fluid; the fluid has a leukocyte count of 6000 per mm3 with no crystals and a negative Gram stain.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids, and occasionally intrabursal glucocorticoids, can be used for crystal-induced or chronic bursitis but are not appropriate until infection is ruled out.

B) CORRECT:

Acute olecranon bursitis may be due to infection or crystal disease. In a generally healthy person with no history of crystal disease, acute bursitis in the setting of skin trauma should raise suspicion for an infected bursa. The presence of fever and marked erythema and tenderness increases the likelihood of septic bursitis. Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism in 80% of cases. Synovial fluid analysis of septic bursitis often reveals lower leukocyte counts than are found in cases of septic arthritis, and the Gram stain may be negative. A leukocyte count >2000 per mm3 is considered consistent with septic bursitis.

In a healthy patient who is not systemically ill, initial therapy should include complete drainage of the bursa and an oral antibiotic with good staphylococcal coverage, such as dicloxacillin. In patients in whom there is a risk of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection, intravenous vancomycin, oral linezolid, and oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are considered appropriate therapies. Serial drainage should be performed in cases in which bursal fluid reaccumulates. Intravenous antibiotics are often needed, even if the organism should be sensitive to oral antibiotics.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for acute olecranon bursitis with significant erythema and swelling in the absence of crystal disease is antibiotic therapy that covers Staphylococcus aureus infection (e.g., dicloxacillin).
Image Description:

There is significant inflammation of the soft tissue overlying the left olecranon process, which appears erythematous and swollen.

C) INCORRECT:

Warm compresses are inadequate for managing a possibly infected bursa.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs may reduce pain and swelling, but treating the underlying infection takes precedence.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is not recommended for the initial treatment of staphylococcal infections; its use can promote the development of resistant organisms.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with no history of arthritis has been experiencing swelling in his left elbow for 2 weeks. He reports no fevers or chills. He works as an accountant and regularly plays tennis. He reports a remote history of radial head fracture as a child.
There is visible swelling over the posterior aspect of the elbow. The swelling is soft, but there is no point tenderness or erythema (figure). He has full range of motion at the elbow, with some discomfort on end flexion.
Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Aspirate the joint, and administer an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection
Recommend conservative treatment with joint protection, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and ice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrabursal injection of glucocorticoids is generally discouraged because of the risk of infection or atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic refractory olecranon bursitis may, in rare instances, require surgical removal of the bursa; referral for bursectomy is not initially indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is not indicated unless there are features of an infection. Aspiration of the bursa would be required if the patient had any features of septic bursitis (fever, erythema, warmth over the elbow, tenderness to palpation) or a secondary skin infection (redness, warmth, streaking up the arm). A septic bursa would require antibiotic therapy and consideration for surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of a bursa is not necessary if there are no features of inflammation (erythema, tenderness, warmth), although fluid aspiration may be done to decompress the bursal sac. Intrabursal injection of glucocorticoids is generally discouraged because of the risk of infection or atrophy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's history and clinical presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of chronic olecranon bursitis. This condition is often called “student’s elbow” because it develops in individuals with a history of repetitive pressure to the bursa, often from resting the elbow on a desk or a hard surface. Chronic olecranon bursitis is usually self-limited and resolves without surgical intervention. Conservative treatment involves providing the patient with joint protection. A hard, removable orthosis can be fitted by an occupational therapist. Antiinflammatory agents such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and application of ice may also be used. Aspiration of a bursa is not necessary if there are no features of inflammation (erythema, tenderness, warmth), although fluid aspiration may be done to decompress the bursal sac.

Key learning point: Initial management of chronic, nonseptic olecranon bursitis consists of conservative treatment with joint protection, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and ice.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man reports 2 weeks of worsening left anterior knee pain and swelling after doing some renovation work at his house. He does not recall any specific injury and has never had similar symptoms before.
He describes mild discomfort at the anterior knee, especially when kneeling. None of his other joints are painful, and he has not been febrile. He has no personal or family history of gout or rheumatologic conditions.
The anterior aspect of his knee is visibly swollen, but no erythema or abrasions are evident. The swelling is ballotable and located directly over the patella. It is minimally tender to palpation, but there is no warmth. The patient can fully extend and flex the knee with free range of motion, but there is mild pain localizing to the anterior knee with end-range flexion. Strength is 5/5 with knee flexion and extension. The rest of the knee examination is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Schedule an ultrasound of the knee
Obtain a radiograph of the knee
Perform diagnostic aspiration of the bursa
Initiate conservative treatment without further investigation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging (ultrasound, MRI, or radiography) is not necessary for patients with typical features of prepatellar bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging (ultrasound, MRI, or radiography) is not necessary for patients with typical features of prepatellar bursitis, although radiography may be appropriate in patients with a history of substantial trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic aspiration of the bursa is indicated if there is any uncertainty as to whether the bursa might be infected. Aspiration would be appropriate in a patient with acute prepatellar bursitis, which typically manifests with an acute onset of warmth, erythema, and tenderness. Some patients may present with fever, and there may be evidence of abrasions or punctures on the skin overlying the patella. Acute prepatellar bursitis is typically caused by infection but can also be caused by gout or hemorrhage. Thus, in patients with erythema, warmth, fever, or leukocytosis, aspiration of the bursa is indicated to differentiate between potential etiologies and to guide therapy. The aspirate should be sent for Gram staining, cell count, culture, and crystal analysis. Of note, the aspiration should be performed by someone with experience aspirating bursae, because the procedure can lead to a nonhealing draining sinus, even in noninfectious etiologies.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic prepatellar bursitis is typically caused by repeated minor trauma to the knee. It manifests with swelling anterior (superficial) to the patella, mild tenderness on palpation or maximal flexion, and an otherwise normal knee examination. Chronic prepatellar bursitis can be diagnosed by history and physical examination alone. Conservative management can be initiated without additional testing. This can be accomplished with a compressive wrap of the patellar bursa and avoidance of the offending microtrauma, whenever possible. If the offending activity cannot be avoided, then a hard knee pad should be used to shield the bursa.

Key learning point: Chronic prepatellar bursitis can be diagnosed from history and physical examination alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Imaging (ultrasound, MRI, or radiography) is not necessary for patients with typical features of prepatellar bursitis, although radiography may be appropriate in patients with a history of substantial trauma.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to the office because of increasing swelling and pain of his right knee for the past month. He has not had any trauma to the knee. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Examination of the right knee shows swelling and erythema; there is fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. The range of flexion is limited because of the pain. The skin over the site of his pain is not warm. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella; there is no joint line tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute gout attacks typically manifest as intense pain and inflammation in the big toe (podagra), knee, fingers, or wrists. However, acute gout attacks usually become maximally painful over a few hours, not one month. In addition, gout usually causes warmth over the affected joint, which is not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis characteristically manifests with monoarticular pain and swelling, as seen in this patient. However, patients with septic arthritis also have systemic signs of infection such as fever and leukocytosis. Additionally, septic arthritis has an acute course and rarely evolves over the course of one month. Finally, because joint infection in septic arthritis occurs via hematogenous spread or direct contamination, most patients will have either a concomitant infection (e.g. endocarditis, abscess) or significant trauma to the affected joint

C) CORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the synovial bursa located between the skin and patella. It is often caused by overuse injuries (such as excessive kneeling, as seen in this case) or repeated trauma to the knee. Professions which require frequent kneeling (e.g., carpet installers, masons, plumbers, mechanics) are especially prone to developing prepatellar bursitis. In acute bursitis, bursal fluid aspiration is indicated to rule out infection or gout. Treatment is conservative and involves rest, ice or heat, elevation, NSAIDs, and, in case of infection, antibiotics. Surgery may be indicated (e.g., drainage of pus, bursectomy) for recurrent bursitis if conservative management fails.

D) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disabling joint disease characterized by a noninflammatory degeneration of the joint complex that occurs with old age or from overuse. Although patients with osteoarthritis can also present with unilateral knee pain, they generally do not have fluctuant edema over the prepatellar bursa. Additionally, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in a 37-year-old patient unless there was a history of significant trauma to the knee.

E) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease commonly manifests as anterior knee pain exacerbated by physical activity in adolescent boys. Patients characteristically have point tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. This diagnosis is unlikely in a 37-year-old with tenderness over the patella and not the tibial tuberosity.
Image Description:

Left knee of a 31-year-old patient

The tibial tuberosity has remained prominent in adulthood (red overlay) secondary to Osgood-Schlatter disease in adolescence.
questions.hint: This condition commonly occurs in individuals with occupations that require excessive kneeling.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with no history of arthritis has been experiencing swelling in his left elbow for 2 weeks. He reports no fevers or chills. He works as an accountant and regularly plays tennis. He reports a remote history of radial head fracture as a child. There is visible swelling over the posterior aspect of the elbow. The swelling is soft, but there is no point tenderness or erythema. He has full range of motion at the elbow, with some discomfort on end flexion. A photograph of the left elbow is shown. Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Aspirate the joint, and administer an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection
Recommend conservative treatment with joint protection, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and ice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intrabursal injection of glucocorticoids is generally discouraged because of the risk of infection or atrophy.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic refractory olecranon bursitis may, in rare instances, require surgical removal of the bursa; referral for bursectomy is not initially indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is not indicated unless there are features of an infection. Aspiration of the bursa would be required if the patient had any features of septic bursitis (fever, erythema, warmth over the elbow, tenderness to palpation) or a secondary skin infection (redness, warmth, streaking up the arm). A septic bursa would require antibiotic therapy and consideration for surgical intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of a bursa is not necessary if there are no features of inflammation (erythema, tenderness, warmth), although fluid aspiration may be done to decompress the bursal sac. Intrabursal injection of glucocorticoids is generally discouraged because of the risk of infection or atrophy.

E) CORRECT:

Olecranon bursitis is often called “student’s elbow” because it develops in individuals with a history of repetitive pressure to the bursa, often from resting the elbow on a desk or a hard surface. Chronic olecranon bursitis is usually self-limited and resolves without surgical intervention. Conservative treatment involves providing the patient with joint protection. A hard, removable orthosis can be fitted by an occupational therapist. Antiinflammatory agents such as nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and application of ice may also be used. Aspiration of a bursa is not necessary if there are no features of inflammation (erythema, tenderness, warmth), although fluid aspiration may be done to decompress the bursal sac.

Key learning point: Initial management of chronic, nonseptic olecranon bursitis consists of conservative treatment with joint protection, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and ice.
questions.hint: This patient's history and clinical presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of chronic olecranon bursitis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to your clinic with a one-month history of increasing swelling and pain in his right knee. He denies any trauma to the knee. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. On examination, the right knee is swollen and erythematous, with fluctuant edema over the lower part of the patella. Flexion is limited due to pain. The skin over the area of pain is not warm. There is tenderness on palpation of the patella, but no joint line tenderness. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis is an inflammation of the synovial bursa located between the skin and patella. It is often caused by overuse injuries (such as excessive kneeling, as seen in this case) or repeated trauma to the knee. Professions which require frequent kneeling (e.g., carpet installers, masons, plumbers, mechanics) are especially prone to developing prepatellar bursitis. In acute bursitis, bursal fluid aspiration is indicated to rule out infection or gout. Treatment is conservative and involves rest, ice or heat, elevation, NSAIDs, and, in case of infection, antibiotics. Surgery may be indicated (e.g., drainage of pus, bursectomy) for recurrent bursitis if conservative management fails.

Key learning point: Prepatellar bursitis presents as swelling and pain over the lower patella due to inflammation of the prepatellar bursa, often from repetitive kneeling or minor trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute gout attacks typically manifest as intense pain and inflammation in the big toe (podagra), knee, fingers, or wrists. However, acute gout attacks usually become maximally painful over a few hours, not one month. In addition, gout usually causes warmth over the affected joint, which is not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disabling joint disease characterized by a noninflammatory degeneration of the joint complex that occurs with old age or from overuse. Although patients with osteoarthritis can also present with unilateral knee pain, they generally do not have fluctuant edema over the prepatellar bursa. Additionally, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in a 37-year-old patient unless there was a history of significant trauma to the knee.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis characteristically manifests with monoarticular pain and swelling, as seen in this patient. However, patients with septic arthritis also have systemic signs of infection such as fever and leukocytosis. Additionally, septic arthritis has an acute course and rarely evolves over the course of one month. Finally, because joint infection in septic arthritis occurs via hematogenous spread or direct contamination, most patients will have either a concomitant infection (e.g. endocarditis, abscess) or significant trauma to the affected joint

E) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease commonly manifests as anterior knee pain exacerbated by physical activity in adolescent boys. Patients characteristically have point tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. This diagnosis is unlikely in a 37-year-old with tenderness over the patella and not the tibial tuberosity.
questions.hint: This condition commonly occurs in individuals with occupations that require excessive kneeling.

Which one of the following initial management approaches is most appropriate in this case?

Recommend conservative treatment with joint protection, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, and ice.

Olecranon bursitis is often called “student’s elbow” because it develops in individuals with a history of repetitive pressure to the bursa, often from resting the elbow on a desk or a hard surface. questions.hint: This patient's history and clinical presentation is most consistent with a diagnosis of chronic olecranon bursitis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents to the ED with a 2-day history of anterior knee swelling and pain. She is otherwise well and reports no other symptoms. She works as a carpet fitter, and has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypercholesterolemia. She takes metformin and atorvastatin. She started a new relationship 9 months ago and reports inconsistent condom use. On examination, there is localized swelling and fluctuance over the kneecap with significant tenderness, erythema, and warmth. Vital signs are normal. She finds walking painful, but passive range of motion at the knee joint is preserved without pain. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge advising rest, ice, NSAIDs and primary care follow-up in 48 hours
Obtain gonorrhea swabs and start empiric treatment for gonococcal arthritis
Perform knee joint arthrocentesis for fluid analysis
Perform bursal aspiration with fluid analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conservative management would be inappropriate given the signs of acute inflammation including erythema, warmth, and significant tenderness.

B) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis evaluation would be appropriate for suspected septic arthritis, but this patient's preserved passive range of motion and localized swelling over the kneecap indicate prepatellar bursitis rather than joint involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Joint arthrocentesis is not indicated as the patient has preserved passive range of motion without joint pain and the swelling is localized to the prepatellar bursa.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with signs of acute inflammation (erythema, warmth, worsening pain), raising concern for septic bursitis. Bursal aspiration with fluid analysis including Gram stain, culture, and cell count is the most appropriate initial diagnostic step to differentiate septic from nonseptic bursitis and guide antibiotic therapy. The patient's diabetes also increases her risk of septic bursitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrabursal glucocorticoid injection is contraindicated when infection is suspected. The presence of erythema, warmth, and significant tenderness suggests possible septic bursitis.
